column1: Jack Peter Benedict Whitehall (born 7 July 1988) is an English comedian
column4: and writer. He is best known for starring as JP in the series Fresh Meat (2011–2016) and Alfie Wickers in the series Bad Education (2012–2014) and its spin-off film The Bad Education Movie (2015). He also co-wrote the latter two. From 2012 to 2018
column5: Whitehall was a regular panellist on the game show A League of Their Own. In 2017
column6: he appeared with his father in the Netflix comedy documentary series Jack Whitehall: Travels with My Father and starred in the television series Decline and Fall. Since 2018
column7: he has been the host of the Brit Awards.

column1: Jack Peter Benedict Whitehall was born at Portland Hospital in London's West End on 7 July 1988
column2: the son of actress Hilary Amanda Jane Whitehall (née Isbister; stage name Hilary Gish) and television producer Michael John Whitehall. His father was also an agent for Judi Dench
column4: and Richard Griffiths. Whitehall is a descendant of Welsh lawyer Thomas Phillips
column5: who was a major opponent of the Newport Rising of 1839. He has a younger sister
column8: Barnaby William Frances (born 10 March 1992). He had two godfathers: actors Nigel Havers and Richard Griffiths. He attended Tower House School in London's East Sheen area
column9: where he was a classmate of actor Robert Pattinson. He has often joked that he resented Pattinson for taking all the best acting roles in the school plays. Whitehall auditioned for the role of Harry Potter in Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (2001)
column10: but the casting director was unimpressed with him because he had not read the book. His parents sent him to boarding school at the age of eight. He attended the Dragon School in Oxford and then Marlborough College
column12: Wiltshire. He took a gap year in which he decided to pursue a career in stand-up comedy. He attended the University of Manchester to study History of Art

column1: Whitehall started stand up comedy performing at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe at the Pleasance Theatre's Comedy Reserve showcase. He had previously taken a sketch show to the Fringe called Comic Abuse. Whitehall won the Amused Moose Laugh Off 2007
column2: and was runner-up in the Laughing Horse New Act of The Year competition
column3: a finalist in So You Think You're Funny?
column4: and winner of the Charlie Harthill Special Reserve in the same year. He was also nominated for 'Best Newcomer' in the 2008 Chortle Awards
column5: and was a finalist in the Hackney Empire New Act of the Year.

column2: Whitehall performed his first solo stand-up show

column2: Whitehall was accused of stealing one of Stewart Lee's stand-up routines for his critically acclaimed Nearly Rebellious show. Lee had performed the joke
column3: which deals with the subject of life after walking in space
column4: at the Montreal Just for Laughs comedy festival in the 1990s
column5: and was filmed for TV by the Comedy Network. When Whitehall recited his version of the routine at the Edinburgh Fringe in 2009
column6: he was described by an otherwise favourable review for Metro as "repeating" Lee's sketch "almost verbatim".On 20 October 2009
column7: Robbie Williams was accused of stealing one of Whitehall's jokes in his much-publicised "comeback" performance as part of the BBC's electric proms at the Camden Roundhouse. When Whitehall originally performed the one-liner
column8: which plays on the phrasal verb "to look down on someone"
column9: it was voted the fifth best joke of the year's Edinburgh Fringe in a poll conducted by TV channel Dave.On 20 June 2010
column10: a photograph of Whitehall appeared in the News of the World
column11: purportedly showing him in possession of cocaine in Manchester. He quickly issued an apology for his behaviour
column12: but did not confirm or deny the allegations. Later that same week

column2: Whitehall performed two shows at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. His third solo stand-up show in succession
column3: Let's Not Speak of This Again. He also performed a series of four stand-up shows with his father Michael Whitehall

column1: He appeared in the first series of Dave's One Night Stand for the comedy network Dave. Recording a stand up performance at London's Haymarket Theatre. The show featured special guests as support.

column2: Whitehall performed two sell out solo shows at the Hammersmith Apollo. These shows completed his debut national tour Let's Not Speak of This Again. Both shows again received highly favourable reviews.On 30 December 2012
column3: Whitehall appeared on The Big Fat Quiz of the Year
column4: during which he made a joke about Queen Elizabeth II. On the next day
column5: complaints were submitted about the joke to Ofcom. Ensuing media speculation led to the National Television Awards stating publicly that Whitehall would not be forced to resign from presenting the awards a short time later.

column1: Whitehall met actress Gemma Chan in 2011
column2: when she guest starred on his series Fresh Meat. They began dating and split up in December 2017. In 2017 Jack gained a 3rd sibling on his travels with his father
column3: Michael Whitehall – a Luk Thep doll which Michael lovingly named Winston. Winston has become a national icon and somewhat of a running joke of Jack’s. As of 2020
column4: he is in a relationship with model Roxy Horner.
